title: Between 1 April 2019 and 31 March 2020, will an armed group from Burundi engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Burundi?
preds: Not the question, I can do not fully understand the answer.  I was already guessing, but when I do a serious research ...

Not exactly a paragon of stability and transparency and things could escalate but sticking to 1 in 20 for now...but at least their president gets to stay in power for 25 more years! And don’t like the opposition? Take their assets! Contrasting that, they need to behave if they want to join SA development group...
https://www.africanews.com/2019/05/17/burundi-to-seize-property-of-govt-critics/ https://citizen.co.za/news/news-africa/2121508/burundi-pushing-for-sadc-membership/

Base rate: between 1%-10% (best guess 2-3%). See here for more info: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/841007 Other judgments: 
- EWP estimate at 7.5%. [1] 
- Crowd forecast here is 0%. Inside view: 
- From EWP: "This small central African country has been in a protracted political crisis since President Pierre Nkurunziza engineered the extension of his term in office in 2015. Burundi’s ranking of 16th for 2018–19 is its lowest in the past three years. As of 2017, V-Dem data reflect that the government of Burundi’s respect for civil liberties no longer varies across different areas of the country, lowering its risk score from our prior assessment. Nevertheless, Burundi continues to exhibit many factors associated with a high risk of mass killing, including a lack of freedom of movement for men, an anocratic regime type, political killings, a history of mass killing, a recent coup attempt, and high infant mortality." [1]
- the post-2015 violence and unrest seem to have calmed down [2]. However, this paywalled article seems to suggest it could get worse [3].
- elections are upcoming next year [4]. It's unclear when exactly. The president has claimed he won't run again. [5]
- media and NGOs have been banned recently apparently. [6] Overall judgment:
- the situation doesn't look very promising. However, since the elections are "only" going to be held next year, I think there are few flash points where violence could erupt again and be sustained sufficiently long.
- my informed gut judgment is 5%. [1] https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/countries/burundi
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burundian_unrest_(2015%E2%80%93present)
[3] https://www.worldpoliticsreview.com/articles/27087/why-burundi-s-ongoing-political-tensions-risk-devolving-into-ethnic-violence
[4] https://theconversation.com/burundi-crisis-looms-as-2020-elections-open-up-old-divisions-110049
[5] https://www.dw.com/en/burundi-president-says-he-wont-stay-beyond-third-term/a-44116159
[6] https://www.hrw.org/news/2019/03/19/bujumbura-can-close-doors-burundi-it-cant-hide-repression
